column8: Flexible portfolio of high-quality carbon offsets
column13: Building a flexible portfolio of high-quality carbon offsets in alignment with our offset procurement framework. Developing knowledge and experience in carbon offsets is considered an essential parallel activity to our decarbonisation plans to mitigate emissions where we are challenged by technology readiness and commercial availability.\t
column20: Carbon Offset Portfolio, Offset Procurement Framework, Emission Mitigation

column13: Recognising we have a role to play now in reducing the carbon footprint of our operations, we have set an industry-leading goal for the Nova Operation to be net zero by 2025. Even with a short remaining mine life, there has been significant investment in the decarbonisation of this operation, including the expansion of the Nova solar farm, which allows the operation to run 'engines-off' for up to nine hours in summer and spring months. Decarbonisation projects at Nova have resulted in emissions savings of 22% since our 2019 baseline.\t
column20: Nova Operation Decarbonization, Solar Farm Expansion, Emissions Reduction

column8: Reducing the Carbon Footprint of Cemented Paste Backfill
column13: A study is underway at the Nova Operation to test delighted beta spodumene (DBS) as a binder material to replace the cement binders used for underground paste backfill partially. The study has been promising, with results determining that DBS can be used in low-binder content applications such as underground paste backfill. There
column20: Beta Spodumene Study, Cement Replacement, Emissions Reduction

column13: We are governed by an offset procurement framework (see page 59) to inform the types of projects we will consider developing or investing in, ensuring we target highly credible ACCUs with secondary solid benefits. We understand that not all carbon credits are of equal value or credibility. Therefore, our framework ensures IGO targets ACCUs aligned with our values and purpose of Making a Difference.\t
column20: Offset Procurement Framework, Credible ACCU Targeting, Secondary Benefits Alignment

column13: Dust emissions are monitored using dust gauges around our operations to provide representative coverage. The dust monitoring data is reviewed to identify trends that can inform management practices.\t
column20: Dust Emissions Monitoring, Management Practices, Environmental Compliance

column13: Each IGO mining operation operates by a project-specific Fibrous Minerals Management Plan. PFM monitoring is completed regularly onsite with personal dust hygiene testing, alongside testing at specific locations around the operations in line with Health and Safety Standards.\t
column20: Fibrous Minerals Management Plan, Onsite Monitoring, Health and Safety Compliance

column6: Nitrogen oxides (NOx), sulfur oxides (SOx), and other significant air emissions
column13: Our water management plans consider the unique hydrological characteristics of the region, and we work closely with local stakeholders and regulatory bodies to ensure compliance with water allocation and quality standards. We prioritise efficient water use by implementing advanced technologies and practices to minimise consumption and maximise recycling and reuse. Through ongoing monitoring and assessment, we strive to mitigate potential impacts on abstracting water resources and take proactive measures to prevent contamination or unsustainable depletion.\t
column20: Air emissions monitoring, dust, pollution\t

column6: Waste generation and significant waste-related impacts
column7: Managing mineral residue and waste rock effectively and responsibly is crucial to our mining operations. Recognising the potential risks and challenges posed by mineral residue and waste rock, we have implemented rigorous systems for identification, containment, treatment and disposal. Through innovative engineering and design solutions, we aim to maximise resource recovery while minimising the generation and release of harmful substances. Our waste management protocols adhere to strict regulatory requirements and industry best practices, ensuring the protection of soil, water, and air quality in the region.

column6: Waste generation and significant waste-related impacts
column13: As part of our ongoing tailings management process, IGO maintains an annual audit schedule to ensure that IGO's facilities are being operated by the mine's operating strategy, safety conditions, prescribed premises conditions, and mining tenement conditions. We use independent external reviews to provide us with the confidence that our facilities are conforming to regulations.\t
column20: Waste management, ecology, sustainability\t

column6: Waste generation and significant waste-related impacts
column13: IGO takes a holistic approach to the way we manage our waste. We seek to positively influence our products' environmental and social impacts through the value chain, including how we manage our waste products.\t
column20: Waste minimisation, recycling, reuse\t

column6: Waste generation and significant waste-related impacts
column13: At IGO, we have implemented strategies and initiatives to minimise waste generation, promote recycling and reuse, and ensure proper disposal of non-mineral waste. We strive to maximise the diversion of waste from landfill, ensuring that recyclable materials are recycled appropriately.\t
column20: Hazardous waste management, policy, sustainability\t

column7: Mineral waste is stored in Tailing Storage Facilities (TSFs). TSFs are reservoirs or dams that store mine tailings, the fine-grained waste rock material suspended in a water slurry discharged from an ore processing plant after extracting the desired metal or mineral. Inappropriate storage or mismanagement of tailings facilities can cause catastrophic safety, health and environmental risks. IGO manages three tailings storage facilities across its operations. At the Nova and Forrestania Operations, the TSFs are active facilities, and the facility at the Cosmos Project is currently inactive; however, it will become active once production commences in FY24.\t

column13: In partnership with Perenti and ABB, IGO is undertaking a study to progress our aspiration of full underground fleet electrification at the Cosmos Nickel Project. The electrification study is a significant step in IGO's target to achieve net zero by 2035 and our commitment to continuously improve sustainability outcomes by trialling new technologies and decarbonising our operations. The study will provide a pathway for the electrification of the mining fleet at Cosmos.\t
column20: Underground Fleet Electrification, Sustainability Initiatives, Technological Advancements

column13: At IGO, we care about the environment and take proactive action to minimise and mitigate our impacts. Environmental risks are managed by legal obligations, corporate policies/standards, and the site Environmental Management System (EMS), aligned with ISO14001.\t
column20: Environmental Impact Mitigation, Environmental Management System, ISO14001 Compliance

column8: Systematic assessments of infrastructure and activities
column13: Systematic assessments of infrastructure and activities are constantly updated to identify significant environmental aspects and to ensure all associated impacts are managed and mitigated by critical controls and processes. Key to maintaining our social licence to operate is complying with all relevant regulations and conditions on our mining tenure.\t
column20: Environmental Risk Management, Regulatory Compliance, Social License to Operate

column13: IGO completes environmental and social impact assessments with the Group Environmental Standard. These assessments help inform the best means by which to mitigate both environmental and social harm, including climate change, water usage, biodiversity loss and unauthorised discharge/emissions. All work programs are subject to environmental and social impact assessments specific to the level of risk for the given work program.\t
column20: Environmental and Social Impact Assessments, Group Environmental Standard, Impact Mitigation

column13: Currently, IGO's single most significant environmental impact is land clearing. Land clearing refers to all vegetation clearing necessary for exploration, construction, infrastructure, access corridors or other purposes. Land clearing is a fundamental pressure on the environment, with the impact compounded by the legacy of extensive historical clearing across Australia.\t
column20: Land Clearing Impacts, Vegetation Clearing, Environmental Pressures

column7: During FY23, we had zero significant environmental incidents across our exploration and operational sites.\t

column13: This year, we renamed our Leadership Award to the Peter Bradford Leadership Award in honour of the late Peter Bradford, who was passionate about the awards and the development of future leaders at IGO and in our industry. This event also celebrates those people in the business who have supported our journey for many years with our IGO Length of Service Awards. While we celebrated those who reached the 5, 7, 10 and 15 years of commitment in 2023, we were excited to celebrate the first IGO person to get 20 years with the Company Ã¢ÂÂ a significant achievement and evidence of their strong commitment to IGO's evolution and our purpose of Making a Difference.\t
